title: Harold Brainsby
text:
Harold Kingsford Brainsby (5 December 1910 – 3 April 1975) was a New Zealand field athlete who won a bronze medal in the <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a> at the <a href="New%20Zealand%20at%20the%201934%20British%20Empire%20Games">1934 British Empire Games</a> in London.
Early life and family.
Born in <a href="Handsworth%2C%20West%20Midlands">Handsworth</a> on the outskirts of <a href="Birmingham">Birmingham</a>, England, in 1910, Brainsby was the son of Edith Anna (née Kingsford) and Arthur Todd Brainsby, a Baptist minister. The family emigrated to New Zealand in 1911. Educated at <a href="Whangarei%20Boys%27%20High%20School">Whangarei High School</a>, Brainsby went on to study at <a href="University%20of%20Auckland">Auckland University College</a>, graduating with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> in 1934, and a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Laws">Bachelor of Laws</a> and Diploma of Journalism in 1938.
On 23 March 1940, Brainsby married Mary Priscilla Wrightson at St Aidan's Church in the <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a> suburb of <a href="Remuera">Remuera</a>, They adopted a daughter in 1957 and divorced in 1960. Harold remarried Diana Kelly and the couple had one son.
Athletics.
Brainsby competed for <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> at the <a href="1934%20British%20Empire%20Games">1934 British Empire Games</a>, where he won the bronze medal in the <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a>, with a distance of . He also competed in the <a href="long%20jump">long jump</a>, finishing in seventh place with a leap of .
He won the triple jump title at the national athletics championships in 1934 and 1935, and was second in the same event but the leading New Zealander (behind Japanese athlete <a href="Kenshi%20Togami">Kenshi Togami</a>) in 1937.
Later life and death.
Brainsby served with the 21st Rifle Battalion, <a href="2nd%20New%20Zealand%20Expeditionary%20Force">2nd New Zealand Expeditionary Force</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He rose from the rank of <a href="sergeant">sergeant</a> to become a <a href="major">major</a> on <a href="Bernard%20Freyberg%2C%201st%20Baron%20Freyberg">General Freyberg</a>'s staff, and returned to New Zealand after the <a href="battle%20of%20El%20Alamein">battle of El Alamein</a>. Following a career as an illustrator and journalist for the "<a href="Auckland%20Star">Auckland Star</a>", "<a href="New%20Zealand%20Herald">New Zealand Herald</a>", and "Auckland Weekly News", in 1952 he joined the <a href="Highland%20Park%2C%20New%20Zealand">Highland Park</a> law firm of Melville Churton, which, in 1962, became Churton Brainsby & Hart.
A noted <a href="contract%20bridge">contract bridge</a> player, Brainsby was a member of the Auckland four that won the New Zealand championship on several occasions. He also served as president of the Northern Bridge Club.
Brainsby died in Auckland on 3 April 1975, and his body was cremated at Purewa.
